title: HW2 Q2
content: Problem context: This is a part of a past final exam question. It should help you appreciate how different optimizers can converge to different solutions when multiple solutions exist. As well as get a better sense for what the inductive bias of the different optimizers is like.
document: Problem context: This is a part of a past final exam question. It should help you appreciate how different optimizers can converge to different solutions when multiple solutions exist. As well as get a better sense for what the inductive bias of the different optimizers is like.

comments.content: Hi, would someone elaborate on what it means by the "inverse of the square roots of the mean squared value for the gradients during the epoch for that specific coordinate"Are these the inverse of the RMS value of a specific gradient component? If so, what does it mean to take the "mean" of that?Thank you
comments.document:
Hi, would someone elaborate on what it means by the "inverse of the square roots of the mean squared value for the gradients during the epoch for that specific coordinate"

Are these the inverse of the RMS value of a specific gradient component? If so, what does it mean to take the "mean" of that?

Thank you

comments.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>+1 my study group & I are also confused w this wording</paragraph><paragraph/></document>
comments.document: +1 my study group & I are also confused w this wording

comments.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Since there's only one training point, you can imagine this as the following simple algorithm:<break/>- Calculate grad_theta.<break/>- M = 1/sqrt(grad_theta**2), elementwise.<break/>- The resulting update is = M * grad_theta.<break/><break/>If you simplify the above procedure out, you'll notice that it solves to be a very simple transformation of the gradient, that you've seen before in lecutre/discussion.</paragraph><paragraph/></document>
comments.document:
Since there's only one training point, you can imagine this as the following simple algorithm:
- Calculate grad_theta.
- M = 1/sqrt(grad_theta**2), elementwise.
- The resulting update is = M * grad_theta.

If you simplify the above procedure out, you'll notice that it solves to be a very simple transformation of the gradient, that you've seen before in lecutre/discussion.

comments.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>That makes sense, but then what happened to the "mean" part? If we can choose to ignore it I agree it makes the problem a lot simpler.</paragraph><paragraph>Also can we make the same assumption about there being one training point for part c?</paragraph></document>
comments.document:
That makes sense, but then what happened to the "mean" part? If we can choose to ignore it I agree it makes the problem a lot simpler.

Also can we make the same assumption about there being one training point for part c?

comments.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Yes, since it's just 1 training point in the epoch, the mean is a no-op!</paragraph></document>
comments.document: Yes, since it's just 1 training point in the epoch, the mean is a no-op!
